awd_titl_txt: Eager: Cyberattacks on Commercial IoT Networks Estimating Large Dimension Parameters for Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract ECCS -1744129
Title: Eager: Cyberattacks on Commercial IoT Networks Estimating Object Position 
Non-technical description: 
While the internet has been available for many years, the integration of sensing and control technology into the internet to yield what is being called the Internet of Things (IoT) is still very immature and brings dangerous new unaddressed security problems.  For example, cyberattacks on automotive processors have already been observed. Car manufacturers are developing critical systems aimed at fusing data from several complex sensors to ensure self-driving automobiles avoid collisions with people and animals. The proposed project will seek to develop a complete theory of commercial IoT/sensor object location estimation network attack mitigation and impact based on: (1) rigorous proofs that the attacked sensors can be identified under some reasonable assumptions and (2) rigorous estimation theory-based analysis of the possible range of performance that the attacked system can achieve. The new theory should lead to technology to protect against cyber attacks on smart homes, smart buildings, smart factories and other commercial IoT/sensor systems relied upon in daily lives. The major portion of the requested funds will go towards supporting graduate students. Educating graduate and undergraduate students, from under represented groups, in these important cross-disciplinary areas will be pursued. Coordination between this research project, classes and Lehigh's Integrated Networks for Electricity (INE) interdisciplinary research initiative is broader impact associated with this project. Research results will be incorporated into current and future Lehigh classes.  Class notes might evolve into a short course, and possibly a book on security of sensing systems, to provide a large educational impact.

Technical description: 
For the object localization problems under consideration, the research will characterize precisely on how observations at each sensor constrain the possible object position when no attacks are present.  The research will also characterize the impact of increasing the number of observations per sensor and the number of sensors when no attacks are present.  Further, the research will analyze the impact of intersecting constraints at multiple sensors to show exactly how the intersected constraints provide a strictly smaller set containing the object location under the case of no attacks.  Large deviation analysis will be used to demonstrate that this approach can properly localize the target with high probability when a sufficient number of observations are available at each sensor.  Cases with fewer observations will be analyzed using appropriate bounds that are accurate with a finite number of observations. These analytical approaches will be employed under attacks to show that significant attacks will drive the intersected constraints to the empty set. Large deviation analysis will be used to establish that this approach can properly identify attacked sensors, under some reasonable assumptions, when a sufficient number of observations are available at each sensor with high probability.  Cases with fewer observations will be analyzed using appropriate bounds that are accurate with a finite number of observations.

por.por_cntn:
The use of sensors in popular internet of things (IoT) systems is becoming common and cyberattacks on these systems have become a great concern. Consider connected sensor-equipped vehicle networks, networks of robots, electrical grid networks, natural gas networks, smart homes, smart businesses, and smart communities.  In these applications, attacks can be very dangerous and cause loss of lives. Thus a better understanding of the theory in this area would greatly help in developing better protection approaches and in training professionals and researchers in this area. 
This project made important theory contributions on our ability to defeat cyberattacks which can effectively alter the sensor data, communications, hardware, or software to cause inappropriate actions by the IoT system. Initially, the focus was on a fairly general class of IoT systems with stationary sensors which are trying to estimate an unknown quantity. The project described sensor system design principles under which one can detect attacks and further determine groups of sensors that are similarly attacked (or unattacked). The project described the optimum processing of the attacked sensor data.  For certain attacks, it was demonstrated that the attacked sensor data can be employed to improve the estimation performance, while for other attacks this is not possible. The project provided necessary and sufficient conditions which can be tested to identify those attacks which make the attacked data useless for improving the estimation of the desired quantity. A specific low complexity protection approach which uses this theory was demonstrated which was shown to provide performance extremely close to the best possible performance that can be obtained.  Later project research extended these ideas for systems of moving sensors with a particular focus on sensor equipped connected vehicle networks and networks of robots.  The developed theory was employed to devise a low complexity approach for near optimum after attack object tracking. 
The team also made important basic contributions to the theory on providing authentication to tell an authorized user or machine that a communicated message comes from a recognized trusted source. As opposed to using the more common cryptographic approaches, a new approach was investigated for wireless communication which embeds a very small signal into transmitted wireless signal, so small that it cannot be noticed or extracted without some shared secret information.  The approach also allows message transmission through the created secure information stream. Performance was extensively evaluated and advantages/disadvantages documented. Enhanced performance was obtained by exploiting some knowledge typically available in many wireless communication approaches.
The team demonstrated a new powerful attack on reinforcement learning algorithms based on no other knowledge of the system under attack other than that obtained by observing its rewards, which can typically be inferred by monitoring the environment. The attack carefully plans into the future to impart maximum damage when restricted to very small perturbations of sensor measurements classifying the system state for the under attack system.  A protection approach was also devised. 
The research work has been published in the top journals and presented at the top conferences so that other researchers might benefit from using our research and build upon it to make further progress. Presentations have been made to the general public in our local community to explain the dangers of cyberattacks and the general ideas behind our research.  Our research group was also interviewed by our local PBS station in a further effort to inform the public about these issues. More formal talks on this topic have been given at some keynote addresses to some audiences not very familiar with cyber security of IoT. Talks focused on cyber security of IoT for students and those who might want to enter this area have been given at various universities throughout the world as part of an IEEE Signal Processing Distinguished Lecturer series. Lectures on this topic were presented at IEEE and NSF oriented summer schools to specifically focus on students interested in further study on these topics. A tutorial was presented at the International Conference on Acoustics, Speech and Signal Processing, a top conference on signal processing and machine learning to help researchers, especially young researchers, to begin working in this area or to enhance their understanding. The team published an IEEE Signal Processing Magazine survey to overview the area so students and new researchers can jump in. This paper (or preliminary versions) was also used as written material for many of the talks just described. Material developed under this research project was presented in undergraduate and graduate classes at Lehigh. PhD students and postdocs have been trained on all aspects of how to perform research.
